IN THE TOUR DE FRANCE, INFORMATION CAN BECOME POWER 

   (af)  
 By IAN AUSTEN   
 c.1999 N.Y. Times News Service   

   ALPE D'HUEZ, France _ At midday on July 5, the American cyclist
Lance Armstrong and the rest of the riders in the Tour de France
were taking things easy when the third of the race's 20 daily
stages began with the riders setting out from the Loire River city
of Nantes, rolling along at a touristlike 18 miles per hour.

   But in Armstrong's team car, just behind the pack of about 175
cyclists, things were anything but restful. One of the team's
directors, Johan Bruyneel, was driving and chomping on a baguette,
occasionally using his knees to handle the steering, as he was
assaulted by an information frenzy.

   From one speaker, Armstrong, who was in second place that day
but is now leading the race, was asking for details on the race
route. On the speaker for Radio Tour, the race's common
communications link, the race director was welcoming a long list of
VIP guests to the race.

   Bruyneel's Nokia hands-free cellular phone chirped the William
Tell Overture to alert him to an incoming call. A tiny Clarion LCD
television that popped out of the in-dash CD player showed
highlights from the previous day's race while a second,
conventional television gave the team mechanic, Juan Lujan, a good
view in the back seat.

   Another radio connected to the team's second car blared
complaints from Mark Gorski, the team's other director, that he was
having trouble hearing.

   The only thing missing, it seemed, was a Global Positioning
System receiver offering the precise position of Armstrong and the
team's seven other riders.

   ``Oh, I wouldn't want that,'' said Bruyneel, his voice now also
competing with the roar of three low-flying television helicopters.
``It's a little bit too high-tech.''

   From a great height, the 96-year-old Tour de France appears to
be quaintly anachronistic, a throwback to the days of solitary
champions and grueling competition, of unruly elements and unlikely
heroes. But along the 2,500-mile route, it is a Superbowl on
wheels, as more than 4,500 team members, cycling officials and
journalists wage their own technological race along the hairpin
turns and mountain roads.

   For the organizers, an increasingly sophisticated array of
electronics helps overcome many of the race's logistical problems.
But for the riders, the technology has begun changing the racing
itself. Teams like Armstrong's have discovered that in a sport
where strategy is as important as speed, information can be power.

   Bruyneel joined the Armstrong team, which is sponsored by the
United States Postal Service, after his own 12-year riding career
ended last season. During his riding days with the Spanish ONCE
team, Bruyneel was one of the first cyclists to use a radio during
the race.

   The experiment was not highly successful. The bulky radios had
to be built into helmets, making them uncomfortably heavy. Because
they were relatively expensive, even well-financed teams could
afford only one or two units. Even worse, the systems generally
proved unreliable. Although cyclists have to keep going even in the
worst weather, the early radio systems were not up to the job.

   But like personal computers, two-way radios have become more
sophisticated and much less expensive since the beginning of the
decade (although the United States Postal Service team estimates
that it has spent $20,000 on communications equipment).

   The daily dressing ritual for Armstrong and his teammates during
the three-week Tour now includes depositing a tiny two-way radio in
a back jersey pocket. The rider then threads wires to allow him to
clip a thumbnail-sized microphone under the front of his jersey and
insert an earpiece. Most of the other riders do likewise.

   For George Hincapie, the sprinting specialist on the United
States Postal Service team, the radios have meant the end of a
racing ritual. He no longer has to carry in his back pockets a
palm-size card giving details about that day's stage: the location
of tough climbs, easier flat stretches or treacherous curves.

   ``There's no point _ Johan can now give us much more information
from the car,'' Hincapie said. ``Occasionally we don't take the
radios to a race and we feel completely lost without them.''

   More significantly, the riders' radios allow Bruyneel to shape
the team's strategy during the race. Rather like deskbound office
workers, professional cyclists must endure seemingly endless
meetings where each team member's responsibilities for that day's
race are laid out. Of course, the actual race rarely fits the plan.

   Dropping back to a team car for advice was not always an option
in the past, especially if the inevitable unforeseen development
involved a big increase in speed. When that happened, the team
leader would generally make a not always fully informed decision
and try to relay it to his team.

   Now Bruyneel simply analyzes the situation and broadcasts a
revised plan. ``It has changed the race a lot,'' Bruyneel said
while flicking the steering wheel to allow another team car and a
photographer's motorbike to pass on the narrow road. ``The
directors have much more control over the teams now.''

   On the day the Tour left Nantes, for example, two riders had
pulled ahead of the main group in a breakaway, which meant that the
best Hincapie could hope to do in a sprint was place third.
``George, it's not worth the energy to go for the sprint,''
Bruyneel advised via radio.

   nn

   While the radio gives Bruyneel more control, it also allows
dissenters to weigh in. The order not to participate in the sprint
was immediately followed by a transmission from Armstrong. ``Ah,
come on,'' he said in a lighthearted attempt at insurrection. ``Go
for it. You can do it!''

   Similarly, Armstrong used the system to great effect during a
time trial later in the week that put him in the race leader's
yellow jersey. Bruyneel radioed a warning that he was about to pass
his greatest rival in the race against the clock, Abraham Olano,
even though Armstrong had started two minutes behind Olano.

   Like everyone at the race, Bruyneel depends on Radio Tour to
develop strategy. The Radio Tour system appeared in a crude form in
the late 1960s and has evolved into an extensive operation.
Controlled from two station wagons with antenna forests on their
roofs that travel in front of and behind the race, the system uses
three airplanes flying at 3,000 feet to relay its transmissions
over routes that generally stretch over 125 miles or more each day.

   On the ground, about 50 official cars, vans and motorbikes of
the tour organizer, Societe du Tour de France, feed information
into Radio Tour through the antenna-laden cars. Some, particularly
the red Lancia carrying the race director, Jean Marie Leblanc, let
everyone else know what's happening in the race.

   Other transmissions make sure that the hundreds of cars and
trucks ahead and behind the race do not become tangled up with the
riders.

   But the airspace above the Tour is no less crowded. In addition
to the three Radio Tour planes and the three television
helicopters, five airplanes fly overhead to relay live commercial
radio and television signals.

   The biggest danger now facing the Tour is that its
communications system will turn into an electronic Tower of Babel.
Because local cellular phone equipment can be overwhelmed by the
estimated 3,000 wireless handsets carried by race followers, France
Telecom now unfolds special truck-mounted high-capacity cellular
towers at the start and finish of each day's event.

   Fights over radio frequencies are also developing. The Societe
du Tour de France alone operates on 258 radio frequencies. In an
attempt to keep order, the French government agency responsible for
assigning radio frequencies has sent technicians to the race for
the first time this year.

   ``It's not us who has the problem now, it's them,'' said Didier
Blondel, the head of telecommunications for the Tour, with obvious
relief.

   Still, problems persist. On the way out of Nantes, the United
States Postal Service riders mysteriously found themselves
receiving instructions intended for a rival French team, Credit
Agricole. Bryneel took it in stride: ``At least they'll have no
secrets from us.''

   Right now, with the exception of television, most of the Tour's
communications use old-fashioned analog systems rather than
higher-capacity digital devices. Blondel said that brief
experiments with digital radio showed that it had trouble coping
with rainstorms and the mountains.

   Nevertheless, Blondel is dreaming of a digital future. He
sketched out his Tour car of the future while sitting in his
office, which, even though it is housed in a fold-out trailer
truck, nevertheless has several Gallic touches, including a potted
artificial rose bush.

   His dream car would have integrated LCD screens on the
dashboards and seat backs. A computer behind the back seat would
receive and decode digital television signals, a digital version of
Radio Tour and Web pages from the Tour's site.

   ``It's too expensive to do this now and the technology isn't
perfected, but it will come,'' Blondel promised, presenting his
drawing with a flourish.

   Until that happens, Bruyneel will continue with his cellular
phones, radios and televisions while steering with his knees
through narrow roads filled with rabid European cycling fans. He
is, as the French say, ``au four, au moulin'' _ ``in the oven, in
the mill'' _ the closest phrase in French to ``multitasking.''
